title: Yahoo Account Hacked? Here’s What to Do

steps.title: Go to Yahoo's Sign-in Helper in any web browser.
steps.content: Go to Yahoo's Sign-in Helper in any web browser. If your Yahoo account was hacked and you can no longer sign in, go to https://login.yahoo.com/forgot in any web browser. If you are using a phone or tablet, follow these steps in a web browser instead of the Yahoo Mail app. If opening Yahoo Mail takes you to your inbox, the hacker hasn't signed you out. You can skip ahead to Securing Your Account (Desktop) or Securing Your Account (Mobile) .

steps.title: Enter your phone number or recovery email and click Continue.
steps.content: Enter your phone number or recovery email and click Continue . In the text box in the middle of the page, type in the phone number or recovery email address you have on file for your Yahoo account.

steps.title: Retrieve your verification code.
steps.content: Retrieve your verification code. Click Yes, text me an Account Key for a phone number or Yes, send me an Account Key for a recovery email address, then do the following: Phone number — Open your phone's messaging app, open the text from Yahoo, and review the 8-character code in the message. Email address — Open your recovery email address inbox, open the Recover access to your Yahoo account email from Yahoo, and review the 8-character code in the middle of the email. If you entered your Yahoo email address, enter the missing numbers or letters from the recovery option listed, then follow one of the above substeps depending on whether you have a phone number or an email address on file.

steps.title: Enter your verification code and click Verify.
steps.content: Enter your verification code and click Verify . Type the 8-character verification code you retrieved into the text box in the middle of the page. Yahoo will automatically capitalize any letters.

steps.title: Select your account if prompted.
steps.content: Select your account if prompted. If you have multiple Yahoo accounts that use your phone number or recovery email address, click the one you want to recover to recover your account.

steps.title: Tap the "y" icon at the top-right corner.
steps.content: Tap the "y" icon at the top-right corner. A menu will expand.

steps.title: Tap Manage Accounts.
steps.content: Tap Manage Accounts . You'll find this option near the top of the pop-out menu.

steps.title: Tap Account info below your Yahoo Mail address.
steps.content: Tap Account info below your Yahoo Mail address.

steps.title: Tap Recent activity.
steps.content: Tap Recent activity . It's near the bottom of the screen. If prompted to enter your password (or, on an iPhone, your Touch ID), do so before proceeding.

steps.title: Tap View all recent activities.
steps.content: Tap View all recent activities . It's below the short list of recent activities. If your account has been compromised, you'll likely see a location you don't recognize in this list. Changing your password will automatically log your account out on all devices except the one you're using.

steps.title: Change your password.
steps.content: Change your password. Tap Change your password above the list, and follow the on-screen instructions to create a new password. Once changed, anywhere you (or the hacker) was signed in before will be logged out.

steps.title: Tap the back button and select Security.
steps.content: Tap the back button and select Security . This takes you to additional security settings for your account.

steps.title: Enable two-step verification.
steps.content: Enable two-step verification. Two-step verification requires you to have access to both your Yahoo login information and a separate form of identification (e.g., your phone or a recovery email address) to log in, making it impossible for anyone who doesn't have access to your phone or recovery address to hack your account. Tap Turn on under "2-Step Verification." Select a verification method. You can receive your sign-in codes as a push notification in the Yahoo Mail app on your phone or tablet, as a text to your phone number, using an authenticator app, or using a physical security key. Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the setup.

steps.title: Check your recovery email and phone number information.
steps.content: Check your recovery email and phone number information. If you're no longer on the Security tab, tap the back button, then select Security to return there. Scroll down to the "Verification Methods" section and make any needed changes. If you see any unfamiliar email addresses or phone numbers here, tap Remove to remove them. Make sure you still have access to the email address and password listed here. If not, tap Add email and Add phone number to add new ones.

steps.title: Check all of your Yahoo Mail settings.
steps.content: Check all of your Yahoo Mail settings. After securing your account, go through your Yahoo Mail settings to ensure nothing looks out of the ordinary. The hacker may have changed your name or forwarded your messages to another location. To access your settings, tap the "y" menu and select Settings .

steps.title: Click your profile icon in Yahoo Mail.
steps.content: Click your profile icon in Yahoo Mail. You'll see it at the top-right corner of your inbox when you're signed in.

steps.title: Click Account Info.
steps.content: Click Account Info . Doing so opens a new page with your Yahoo account information listed.

steps.title: Click Review recent activity.
steps.content: Click Review recent activity . It's near the bottom of the page.

steps.title: Review your recently signed-in locations.
steps.content: Review your recently signed-in locations. You'll see a list of all the locations where your Yahoo account is logged in. If your account has been compromised, you'll likely see a location you don't recognize in this list. Changing your password will automatically log your account out on all devices except the one you're using.

steps.title: Change your password.
steps.content: Change your password. Click Change your password above the sign-in list, and follow the on-screen instructions to create a new password.

steps.title: Click the Security tab.
steps.content: Click the Security tab. It's at the top of the page.

steps.title: Turn on Two-Step Verification.
steps.content: Turn on Two-Step Verification. Two-step verification is a feature that makes it impossible for someone with just your login information to hack your account—they would also have to have access to your phone or your recovery email address. Click Turn on under "2-Step Verification". Select a verification method. You can receive your sign-in codes as a push notification in the Yahoo Mail app on your phone or tablet, as a text to your phone number, using an authenticator app, or using a physical security key. Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the setup. If you clear your current browser's cookies or remove a signed-in location from the Recent activity menu, you'll have to re-validate your account with two-step verification the next time you log in.

steps.title: Check your recovery email and phone number information.
steps.content: Check your recovery email and phone number information. If you're no longer on the Security tab, click it at the top of the page to return there, then scroll down to the "How we make sure it's really you" section. If you see any unfamiliar email addresses or phone numbers here, click Remove to remove them. Make sure you still have access to the email address and password listed here. If not, click Add email and Add phone number to add new ones.

steps.title: Check all of your Yahoo Mail settings.
steps.content: Check all of your Yahoo Mail settings. After securing your account, go through your Yahoo Mail settings to ensure nothing looks out of the ordinary. The hacker may have changed your name or forwarded your messages to another location. To access your settings, click Settings at the top-right corner of your inbox.

steps.title: Contact Yahoo Customer Care.
steps.content: Contact Yahoo Customer Care. Yahoo recommends speaking with their Customer Care team for expert tips on getting back into your hacked account. [1] X Research source You have a few options for contacting them: Call (800) 745-0739 for premium (paid) support. [2] X Research source Send a message to Yahoo Customer Care through their Facebook Page . Send a direct message on X/Twitter to @YahooCare .

steps.title: You suddenly can't get into your Yahoo account.
steps.content: You suddenly can't get into your Yahoo account. If your password stops working but you haven't changed it, your account may be compromised.

steps.title: Your contacts are receiving messages from your address.
steps.content: Your contacts are receiving messages from your address. If your friends, family, and others are receiving emails from "you" that you didn't send, a hacker may be trying to spam or scam them.

steps.title: Your settings were changed.
steps.content: Your settings were changed. Hackers may change your name or customize other settings in Yahoo Mail if they take over your account.

steps.title: You find recent logins that you don't recognize.
steps.content: You find recent logins that you don't recognize. If you see any unfamiliar locations and devices in your recent activity list, somebody has likely gained access to your account.
